title: A Question Over the Reach of Europe’s ‘Right to Be Forgotten’
summary: A man’s victory in a Paris court could set a precedent that Europe’s “right to be forgotten” ruling should apply far more broadly than originally understood.

title: In Net Neutrality Push, F.C.C. Is Expected to Propose Regulating Internet Service as a Utility
summary: Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, is expected to propose reclassifying high-speed Internet as a telecommunications service.

title: Raspberry Pi Computer Gains More Horsepower
summary: The low-cost computing device, popular with hobbyists and students, can do more than ever. But it will still cost $35.

title: Uber to Open Center for Research on Self-Driving Cars
summary: The ride-hailing service is partnering with Carnegie Mellon University, a hotbed for research in robotics and other artificial intelligence.

title: Alibaba and Lending Club to Form Financing Partnership
summary: The partnership will provide financing for U.S. manufacturers to buy products and supplies through Alibaba.com.

title: Cisco Makes Its Annual Predictions on Mobile Data Traffic
summary: Cisco’s annual outlook for mobile traffic projects a tenfold increase in mobile traffic, at higher speeds, between 2014 and 2019. Even more traffic is expected to go over Wi-Fi networks.

title: Obama’s Budget Seeks International Minimum Tax for Corporations
summary: A tax on foreign earnings trapped overseas is best thought of as a jobs-friendly international minimum tax, writes Victor Fleischer in the Standard Deduction column.

title: Tim O’Reilly Explains the Internet of Things
summary: The publisher and web guru says the Internet is about to cause its greatest changes, augmenting people with sensors and ever-present computing to create entirely new economic systems, and new ways of thinking about politics.

title: F.C.C. Plans Strong Hand to Regulate the Internet
summary: The proposal would create legal authority to ensure that no content is blocked and that the Internet is not divided into fast and slow lanes.

title: Traveling With an iPhone
summary: Using your phone as a GPS unit is handy, but can run the battery down. Always pack a mobile phone charger.

title: Twitter and Google Said to Reach Deal on Search
summary: The microblogging service is expected to announce a partnership that will make tweets easier to find in Google search results.

title: Twitter’s Revenue Grows Despite User Stagnation
summary: The company said it had 288 million regular users in the last quarter, fewer than analysts’ expectations of about 291 million.

title: Limit ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ to Europe, Panel Tells Google
summary: An eight-person committee advising Google on complying with a landmark privacy ruling by Europe’s highest court said it should apply only in the 28-nation European Union.

title: Dick Costolo of Twitter on Earnings Report
summary: CNBC interview with Dick Costolo, Twitter’s chief executive, who discusses his company’s earnings, user growth strategy and partnership with Google.

title: New Data Shows Apple’s Explosive Growth in China
summary: Both Kantar Worldpanel and Canalys, research firms that track global smartphone sales, said Apple’s mobile operating system gained market share in China at the expense of Google’s Android.

title: As Technology Entrepreneurs Multiply in Vietnam, So Do Regulations
summary: A growing list of government rules dictates how technology businesses must be run, including what they can do with their content.

title: Uncovering Security Flaws in Digital Education Products for Schoolchildren
summary: The law has long treated educational information as a category worthy of special protections, like credit or medical records, but the reality is often different.

title: Comcast-Time Warner Cable Deal Still Up in the Air a Year Later
summary: The air of inevitability around Comcast’s proposed $45 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable has dissipated as the F.C.C. prepares to vote on a proposal to regulate the Internet like a utility.

title: A Prickly Partnership for Uber and Google
summary: Google is a major investor in Uber, but as often happens in Silicon Valley, each company is working on products that could directly compete with the other’s.

title: Daily Report: Rivalry Brewing Between Uber and Google
summary: Google is a major investor in Uber, but as often happens in Silicon Valley, each company is working on products that could wind up directly competing.

title: Morning Agenda: U.S. Takes On Payday Lenders
summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau seeks to limit payday lenders. | The prime minister of Greece says he will carry out his campaign to roll back austerity. | Hidden cash is flowing into high-end real estate. | Shares of HSBC fall on tax avoidance claims.

title: Twitter Reports a Surge in Government Data Requests
summary: The report said total government requests for data rose by 40 percent, to about 2,881, compared with the company’s last report, in July.

title: Sidecar, a Ride-Hailing Start-Up, Pushes Into Package Delivery
summary: Sidecar said it planned to use its fleet of cars to power a package delivery service, delivering items like food and groceries for partner companies.

title: Microsoft and Samsung End Legal Dispute
summary: Almost six months after Microsoft sued Samsung, accusing it of violating the terms of a patent licensing agreement, the two companies on Monday said they had settled their feud.

title: A New Mobile Map Captures ‘Internet of Moving Things’
summary: A start-up has released a map for mobile phones that does impressive stuff without connecting to cloud-computing services. More important than its flashy augmented reality is a new kind of database it uses.

title: Yelp Buys Eat24, an Online Food-Ordering Service, for $134 Million
summary: The move is a departure for Yelp, which has long been a platform for online reviews across many industries, including home services and retail stores.

title: Twitter Finance Chief’s Account Briefly Seized by Spammer
summary: The social network says that the account of its chief financial officer, Anthony Noto, was used to send a blast of spam on Tuesday. The company is investigating the incident.

title: Yelp Pays $134 Million for Food-Ordering Service
summary: The move is a departure for Yelp, whose main business has been selling advertising bought by local businesses with those reviews.

title: Importing Images to iPhoto
summary: Tips on how to transfer photographs into iPhoto on your Mac, and advice for connecting to a virtual private network from a mobile device.

title: Survey of Foreign Companies in China Finds Pollution a Growing Problem
summary: The report by the American Chamber of Commerce reflects on-the-ground attitudes that large Chinese cities have become less hospitable places to work.

title: Google, Mighty Now, but Not Forever
summary: The tech giant is trying to evolve beyond a search behemoth, but it faces the same problems as the once-mighty tech companies that came before it.

title: Microsoft Continues Mobile Push With Sunrise Acquisition
summary: The company has acquired Sunrise Atelier, maker of the popular Sunrise calendar app for iOS, Android and Mac. The companies are not disclosing the sale price.

title: Jet.com Gets Investment That Values It at $600 Million
summary: A soon-to-start online marketplace that aims to loosen Amazon’s grip on e-commerce raises $140 million.

title: Twitter’s Chief Sees Plenty of Money in Tweet Flow
summary: Dick Costolo, chief executive of the social network, sketched out his plans for bringing in new revenue, from showing more ads in the feeds of Twitter users to helping brands hire popular users to create sponsored video content.

title: Aiming to Ease App Discovery, Apple Pairs With Pinterest
summary: App Pins aims to do for smartphone apps what Pinterest’s service has done for photos, recipes and many other types of websites. In short, the service is a type of digital corkboard that lets visitors save, or “pin,” items they like or places they want to go.

title: Daily Report: Google Is a Mighty Force Now, but That May Not Last Forever
summary: The tech giant is trying to evolve beyond a search behemoth, but it faces the same problems as the once-mighty tech companies that came before it.

title: Expedia to Acquire Orbitz as Travel Sites Consolidate
summary: The transaction further solidifies the American market for online travel booking to two companies, Expedia and the much bigger Priceline Group.

title: Obama Heads to Tech Security Talks Amid Tensions
summary: President Obama’s cybersecurity meeting with the nation’s top tech firms comes at a time of deepening estrangement between Silicon Valley and Washington.

title: Daily Report: Obama Heads to Security Talks Amid Tensions
summary: A long history of quiet cooperation between Washington and America’s top technology companies has been shattered by tension over the government’s use of technology companies for its intelligence purposes.

title: Morning Agenda: Standoff Over Greek Debt
summary: All sides in the negotiations on Greek debt are betting others will blink first. | Lyft is is talks to raise about $250 million. | Expedia agrees to buy Orbitz. | Law schools are adding business-related offerings.

title: China’s Internet Restrictions Are Hampering Business, Foreign Companies Say
summary: Businesses are growing increasingly frustrated by obstacles to Internet access, according to a survey by the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China.

title: Obama Calls for New Cooperation to Wrangle the ‘Wild West’ Internet
summary: The president signed an executive order urging companies to exchange data on cyberthreats and receive classified information from the government.

title: Slice and Carve: The Next Wave in Computer-Aided Creativity
summary: Laser cutters and computer-controlled milling machines are coming out of industrial workshops and planting themselves on desktops.

title: Cellphone Start-Ups Use Wi-Fi First to Handle Calls and Take On Rivals
summary: Two start-ups are trying to lower cellphone costs by relying on Wi-Fi routers, and now some of the bigger companies are looking to follow their lead.

title: David Carr’s Last Word on Journalism, Aimed at Students
summary: Mr. Carr, who died Thursday, was a funny, demanding, optimistic teacher of reporters-to-be at Boston University, and his syllabus distills his sense of an unfolding digital age. Excerpts here serve as the final Media Equation column under his byline.

title: Hoping Google’s Lab Is a Rainmaker
summary: After patiently abiding a steep increase in research and development spending, Wall Street is starting to wonder when — and if — Google’s science projects will pay off.

title: Popular Demand
summary: Every tweet, video or comment online has branding power, just like ads on television or online.

title: Astro Teller, Google’s ‘Captain of Moonshots,’ on Making Profits at Google X
summary: Astro Teller, the head of the Google X research group, talks about the company’s efforts to commercialize projects like the self-driving car and why the Glass wearable device will still impact technology.

title: IBM, G.E. and Others Create Big Data Alliance
summary: A number of big tech companies with an interest in building out the big data market have announced a standard for core elements of a technology framework for data analysis.

title: Securing a Hotmail Account
summary: How to use two-step verification to guard against unauthorized access to your email.

title: Photoshop at 25: A Thriving Chameleon Adapts to an Instagram World
summary: Adobe, which introduced the image-editing program in 1990, has moved to a less expensive subscription-based model in an effort to democratize access.

title: Same-Day Delivery Resurges, Adding Alcohol
summary: Millennials accustomed to ordering food for delivery on smartphones have come of legal drinking age, and niche start-ups are poised to take advantage.

title: Microsoft Has Suddenly Gotten Serious With Mobile
summary: There’s a new strategy afoot at the company, which has brought apps and services to the Apple and Android devices people actually use, rather than ones that run Windows.

title: Dropcam Keeps an Eye on the Neighborhood
summary: Setting up video surveillance on a driveway highlights the power of putting such tools in the hands of ordinary people.

title: Daily Report: Microsoft Zeroes In on Mobile
summary: There’s a new strategy afoot at the company, which has brought apps and services to the Apple and Android devices people actually use, rather than ones that run Windows.

title: Yahoo Courts Mobile App Makers with New Tools
summary: Building on its acquisition of the start-up Flurry last year, the Internet company is seeking to broaden its influence with mobile application developers by offering them better analytic and advertising services.

title: F.D.A. Reverses Course on 23andMe DNA Test in Move to Ease Restrictions
summary: The agency approved a test that would be administered to parents to see if they carry mutations that could cause a rare disorder called Bloom syndrome in their children.

title: Ellen Pao Suit Against Kleiner Perkins Heads to Trial, With Big Potential Implications
summary: A high-profile harassment lawsuit brought against the prominent venture capital firm comes as attention mounts on gender issues in Silicon Valley.

title: Google and Apple Fight for the Car Dashboard
summary: In the coming months, dealerships around the country will begin selling vehicles capable of running Android- and Apple-compatible dashboard systems.

title: Once-Popular Car Technologies at the End of the Road
summary: With technology in automobiles becoming increasingly sophisticated, some products are destined for the trash heap.

title: Daily Report: Automakers Close to Widely Adopting Dashboard Tech From Google and Apple
summary: In the coming months, auto dealerships around the country will begin selling vehicles capable of running Android- and Apple-compatible dashboard systems.

title: IBM Tries to Paint the Computing Cloud Blue
summary: IBM is going deeper in the plan of its chief, Virginia Rometty, to rebuild the computing giant as a cloud company. At a giant show in Las Vegas, the company announced new kinds of security and services for cloud applications, along with data centers in new countries.

title: Google Guns for Apple in Mobile Payments Race
summary: The use of so-called proximity payment services is expected to accelerate in the coming year and Google isn’t ready to cede the market to companies like Apple and Samsung.

title: Filing Away Gmail Messages
summary: Tips on how to archive Gmail messages to tidy up your inbox, and solutions for when your laptop battery begins to fade.

title: Tough Talk From European Commissioner About U.S. Tech Companies
summary: Günther Oettinger, the European Commission member in charge of the digital economy, said that if companies did not comply with European data rules, they “ultimately, perhaps, may be thrown out of the single market.”

title: Onetime Mystery Informant in Galleon Insider Trading Case Gets No Jail Time
summary: Thomas Hardin, who worked for the hedge fund Lanexa Management, got some of his tips from the same woman who gave information to Galleon’s founder.

title: F.C.C. Net Neutrality Rules Clear Hurdle as Republicans Concede to Obama
summary: The Republican resistance in Congress surrendered to President Obama’s call to protect an open Internet, with rules likely to be approved by regulators on Thursday.

title: Stretching a City’s Limits
summary: When Google moved to Mountain View, Calif., in 1999, it had a dozen employees and was known only to computer aficionados.

title: U.S. and British Agencies May Have Tried to Get SIM Encryption Codes, Gemalto Says
summary: The digital security company said it believed attacks by the N.S.A. and its British counterpart occurred over two years, starting in 2010.

title: Stretching a City’s Limits
summary: When Google moved to Mountain View, Calif., in 1999, it had a dozen employees and was known only to computer aficionados. Now, 20,000 local employees make it the biggest employer in a city bursting at the seams.

title: Google Plans New Headquarters, and a City Fears Being Overrun
summary: Google’s sometimes testy relationship with community leaders in Mountain View, Calif., a city already bursting at the seams, is likely to get testier.

title: A Google Computer Can Teach Itself Games
summary: A team at Google has developed a way a computer can sense inputs, learn rules and successfully play a number of classic video games. That’s a step up from the Jeopardy!-winning Watson, which was taught rules.

title: Stretching a City’s Limits
summary: When Google moved to Mountain View, Calif., in 1999, it had a dozen employees and was known only to computer aficionados.

title: Vivek Wadhwa, Voice for Women in Silicon Valley, Is Foiled by His Tone
summary: Mr. Wadhwa was one of the loudest male voices pushing for gender diversity in Silicon Valley. His story is a lesson in how not to handle criticism.

title: Apple Loses Patent Case to Small Texas Company
summary: The computer giant was ordered to pay $532.9 million to Smartflash, which is based in a building down the street from where the trial was held. Apple plans to appeal.

title: The Push for Net Neutrality Arose From Lack of Choice
summary: Regulating the Internet like a utility makes sense, proponents say, because Americans often have only one option for high-speed service: cable.

title: Privacy Group Files F.T.C. Complaint Against Samsung’s Voice-Operated TVs
summary: The Electronic Privacy Information Center accused Samsung of violating federal laws with a technology that allows viewers to operate the company’s Internet-connected smart TVs with voice commands.

title: F.C.C. Approves Net Neutrality Rules, Classifying Broadband Internet Service as a Utility
summary: The agency’s 3-2 vote is intended to ensure a level playing field for Internet content providers, with no so-called pay-to-play fast lanes.

title: Google Puts European Operations Under a Single Executive
summary: Google, which is facing various regulatory issues in Europe, has consolidated the region’s operations under a single executive.

title: Will.i.am Start-Up Hires Sony Electronics Executive
summary: Phil Molyneux, who most recently was president and chief operating officer of Sony Electronics in the United States, will take on the same role at i.am+, a 60-person wearables start-up.

title: Amazon Hires Jay Carney, Former Obama Press Secretary
summary: Amazon has hired Mr. Carney as senior vice president for global corporate affairs. The move is unusual, as Amazon is known for grooming employees from within.

title: Dutch Offer Preview of Net Neutrality
summary: As with the rules adopted by the F.C.C., the Netherlands demands that wireless and fixed-line broadband providers treat all Internet traffic equally.

title: Kobalt, Music Services Company, to Announce $60 Million in New Investment
summary: The company, which handles music publishing rights, will use the money to expand its extensive data-tracking system.

title: At Aetna, a C.E.O.’s Management by Mantra
summary: Mark Bertolini, the chief executive of Aetna, is betting that bringing yoga, meditation and higher wages to his employees will be good business.

title: Google Unveils Plan for New Corporate Campus
summary: Google unveiled a radical proposal for a new campus that would replace its current headquarters in Mountain View.

title: Apple’s New Job: Selling a Smartwatch to an Uninterested Public
summary: The Apple Watch is scheduled to debut in April, a bit later than the company had hoped, because of technology challenges.

title: Samsung Galaxy S6 and Galaxy S6 Edge, Unveiled at Mobile World Congress, Offer Best of iPhone and More
summary: Samsung has been accused of being a copycat, but after adding its own design twists to popular features borrowed from the competition, its new flagship phone feels like a real flagship.
